description: From Middle English rimpel, rympyl, from Old English *hrimpele, hrympelle (“wrinkle, rimple”), from Proto-Germanic *hrumpiljǭ, related to Old English hrimpan (“to wrinkle, rimple”), from Proto-Germanic *hrimpaną (“to bend, curve, make waves, wrinkle”).

verbs.description: rimple (third-person singular simple present rimples, present participle rimpling, simple past and past participle rimpled)

entries.meaning: (now chiefly US) To wrinkle or crease. [from 15th c.]
examples: The evening was fine, and the air so still, that it scarcely waved the light leaves of the trees around, or rimpled the broad expanse of the waters below.
